abstract.text: Shading based on a realistic abstraction of physical lights and materials.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Physically-based shading incorporates a refined model of the interactions between real-world lights and materials. Using modern GPU hardware and algorithms, this model can produce more realistic results than the loose abstractions of traditional shading, while also offering a set of material properties that is easier for artists to work with. Especially when combined with environmental lighting (see the
property) and high dynamic range cameras (see the
property), physically-based shading can produce realistic results similar to those seen in recent animated feature films.
Physically based shading relies primarily on three material properties:
The
property (called albedo in some authoring tools) provides the “base” color of a material.
The

property (inverted and called smoothness in some authoring tools) is an approximation of the microscopic detail in a real-world surface. By approximating these “microfacets” as a single term, this property helps produce lighting calculations that resemble the energy-conserving laws of real-world physics, resulting in more realistic variation between matte and shiny surfaces.
The

property approximates other aspects of a physical surface, such as index of refraction, tendency to produce sharp reflections, and tendency to produce Fresnel reflections at grazing angles, which together produce an overall metallic or nonmetallic (also called dielectric) appearance.
In addition, you can add surface detail to a physically based material with the
and
properties, and modulate the contribution of environmental lighting with the
property.
Physically based materials ignore the
, and
material properties and the
, and
parameters.
Physically based rendering requires a Metal renderer. When displaying a material in a view whose
value is not
, SceneKit falls back to rendering that material with the

lighting model. (Metal rendering is not supported in Simulator or Xcode Playgrounds when targeting iOS or tvOS, and is not available at all in watchOS, so this fallback always occurs in those environments.)

abstract.text: Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
A set of camera attributes that can be attached to a node to provide a point of view for displaying the scene.
A Boolean value that determines whether SceneKit applies High Dynamic Range (HDR) postprocessing effects to a scene.
A set of shading attributes that define the appearance of a geometry’s surface when rendered.
Constants specifying the lighting and shading algorithm to use for rendering a material.
Shading that incorporates ambient, diffuse, and specular properties, where specular highlights are calculated using the Blinn-Phong  formula.
Uniform shading that incorporates ambient lighting only.
Shading that incorporates ambient and diffuse properties only.
Shading that incorporates ambient, diffuse, and specular properties, where specular highlights are calculated using the Phong  formula.
Shading based on a realistic abstraction of physical lights and materials.
An object that manages the material’s response to ambient lighting.
An object that provides color values to be multiplied with the ambient light affecting the material.
An object that manages the material’s diffuse response to lighting.
A factor affecting the material’s reflectivity. Animatable.
A Boolean value that determines whether the material responds identically to both ambient and diffuse lighting. Animatable.
An object that provides color values to determine how metallic the material’s surface appears.
An object that defines the nominal orientation of the surface at each point for use in lighting.
An object that defines the reflected color for each point on a surface.
An object that provides color values to determine the apparent smoothness of the surface.
An object that provides color values representing the global illumination of the surface.
The sharpness of specular highlights. Animatable.
An object that manages the material’s specular response to lighting.
Use the Metal framework for SceneKit rendering.
A container for the node hierarchy and global properties that together form a displayable 3D scene.
A cube map texture that depicts the environment surrounding the scene’s contents, used for advanced lighting effects.
The graphics technology SceneKit uses to render the scene.
